title-group.article-title: "To What Shall I Compare You?": Jerusalem as Ground Zero of the Hebrew Imagination

Maurice Halbwachs: "Whatever epoch is examined, attention is not directed toward the first events, or perhaps the origin of these events, but rather toward the group of believers and toward their commemorative work. When one looks at the physiognomy of the holy places in successive times, one finds the character of these groups inscribed" (234-35).

Elaine R. Follis argues that the poetic designa- tion "daughter [of] Zion" or "daughter [of] Jerusalem" is Helleno-Semitic and that both Jerusalem and Athens, more or less concurrently (sixth and fifth centuries BCE), were so designated, not just as a conventional collective personification of a city's inhabitants but also as "divinely favored, the centers of their respective civilizations, close to the heart of the God of Heaven. And both were re- garded in figurative language as the daughter of that high god" (182).
Ricoeur, "if one agrees with Cassirer that myth represents a level of consciousness where tension with the body of our knowledge has not yet appeared" (214).
Goitein, "Biography" and Mediterranean Society 5

Aharon Megged noted an anal- ogy between the Hebrew language and Sleeping Beauty, who, when she awakens from her deep sleep, loses her enchantment and her nobility and must fulfill the mun- dane tasks of the household: "The revival of the Hebrew language is not like Lazarus rising miraculously from the dead. It is more like the Sleeping Beauty awakened by the Prince. She was not dead, she had only been dormant for a long time; and she was not rotten bones but a real beauty. Now when you betrothe her and bring her into your home, your problem is how to make this noble, aristocratic prin- cess, adorned with jewels and clad in purple, do all the domestic work, soil her hands, break her back cooking, washing and tending the garden in the back yard" (31).
